answers.author: Sheri Campbell-Husband
answers.text:
Our City has used it for both emergency and non-emergency communications as well.  We've used it to notify the public when we had to suspend City operations due to inclement weather.  We've posted links to the Road Construction Update on the City's website (see below). We've used it to notify residents of water line breaks, especially those impacting road access.   
"Want to keep track of local road construction and its impact on your travel about town? Visit the City's website to check the Road Construction Update on the homepage. There are a number of road construction projects starting this week."

answers.author: Maggie Healy
answers.text:
In Redondo Beach, CA, we use Facebook and Twitter to post info, events, announcements.   What we didn't truly appreciate until a recent Tsunami Watch was the benefit of not just posting information for our local area, but monitoring Twitter posts about the Tsunami event, from locals as well as people up and down the coast.  It gave our EOC staff a real-time, big-picture perspective that was not available from the media.

answers.author: Thomas Wieczorek
answers.text:
ICMA and the National League of Cities (NLC) have developed a program for local government officials that has now been presented in 45 states. The application and use of Twitter and Facebook is one of the more discussed portions of the program. Several issues have arisen:

The next generation does not use printed material; rather, it looks to electronic means by which to garner information. Facebook and Twitter allow the ability to reach this generation both prior to as well as during an event. The drawback is that Twitter is limited in the amount of information that can be posted.
A court in Michigan is now using Twitter in an attempt to inform the public on changes to proceedings as well as the law. The limit on information is the one drawback noted thus far.
Some states and communities are wrestling with the ability to preserve information for freedom of information requests that may be filed in the future. How much is recoverable?
Most Public Information Officer processes envision data begin collected, transmitted to an Emergency Operation Center where it is vetted for accuracy and content, and then presented to the public. The problem is that the public has often already been given information (accurate and inaccurate) within this time frame and begun making decisions. How will PIO processes need to change in order to meet the aspect of instant information?

Several cities here in the DC Metro used Facebook and Twitter effectively in keeping citizens aware of road closures and shelters opening up during the major snow emergencies of 2010.  
How has your community been incorporating social networking as part of your emergency management plans and related communication?
Please provide sample messages and links to examples.  We will add them to a combined report detailing best practices in the use of social networking in community emergencies.  
Thanks much and we hope everyone enjoys the new Knowledge Network.
title: Social Networking and Emergency Communication
